verses.text: In three \add things\add* I was beautified, And stood up beautiful \add both\add* before God and men: The unity of brethren, the love of neighbours, A man and a wife that agree together.
Three sorts \add of men\add* my soul hateth, And I am greatly offended at their life: A poor \add man that is\add* proud, a rich \add man that is\add* a liar, And an old adulterer that doateth.
If thou hast gathered nothing in thy youth, How canst thou find \add any thing\add* in thine age?
O how comely \add a thing is\add* judgment for gray hairs, And for ancient \add men\add* to know counsel!
O how comely \add is\add* the wisdom of old men, And understanding and counsel to men of honour!
Much experience \add is\add* the crown of old men, And the fear of God \add is\add* their glory.

\add There be\add* nine things \add which\add* I have judged in mine heart to be happy, And the tenth I will utter with my tongue: A man that hath joy of \add his\add* children; And he that liveth to see the fall of \add his\add* enemy:
Well \add is\add* him that dwelleth with a wife of understanding, And that hath not slipped with \add his\add* tongue, And that hath not served \add a man more\add* unworthy than himself:
Well \add is\add* him that hath found prudence, And he that speaketh in the ears of them that \add will\add* hear:
O how great \add is\add* he that findeth wisdom! Yet is there none above him that feareth the Lord.
But the love of the Lord passeth all \add things\add* for illumination: He that holdeth it, whereto shall he be likened?
The fear of the Lord \add is\add* the beginning of his love: And faith \add is\add* the beginning of cleaving unto him.
\add Give me\add* any plague, but the plague of the heart: And any wickedness, but the wickedness of a woman:
And any affliction, but the affliction from them that hate \add me:\add* And any revenge, but the revenge of enemies.
There is no head above the head of a serpent; And there is no wrath above the wrath of an enemy.
I had rather dwell with a lion and a dragon, Than to keep house with a wicked woman.
The wickedness of a woman changeth her face, And darkeneth her countenance like sackcloth.
Her husband shall sit among his neighbours; And when he heareth \add it\add* shall sigh bitterly.
All wickedness \add is but\add* little to the wickedness of a woman: Let the portion of a sinner fall upon her.
As the climbing up a sandy way \add is\add* to the feet of the aged, So \add is\add* a wife full of words to a quiet man.
Stumble not at the beauty of a woman, And desire her not for pleasure.
A woman, if she maintain her husband, \add Is full of\add* anger, impudency, and much reproach.

A wicked woman abateth the courage, \add maketh\add* a heavy countenance and a wounded heart: \add A woman\add* that will not comfort her husband in distress \add maketh\add* weak hands and feeble knees.
Of the woman \add came\add* the beginning of sin, And through her we all die.
Give the water no passage; Neither a wicked woman liberty to gad abroad.
If she go not as thou wouldest have \add her\add*, Cut her off from thy flesh, \add And\add* give \add her a bill of divorce\add*, and let \add her\add* go.
